entry.title: Re: Need help with SP_TransactionNotification
entry.content:
Hello, 

You don't need to check the UserSign field from the table, but rather the new parameter user_id (ID of the user currently logged in to SAP Business One).

ALTER PROCEDURE SBO_SP_TransactionNotification
(
in object_type nvarchar(30), -- SBO Object Type
in transaction_type nchar(1), -- [A]dd, [U]pdate, [D]elete, [C]ancel, C[L]ose
in num_of_cols_in_key int,
in list_of_key_cols_tab_del nvarchar(255),
in list_of_cols_val_tab_del nvarchar(255),
in user_id int
)
...

SELECT COUNT ("UserSign") INTO cnt
FROM "@IVZ_DOC_AT"
WHERE "Code" = :list_of_cols_val_tab_del
AND (:user_id <> 124) ;
...

entry.title: Re: Standard Message type for the Inbound IDOC 944 for Po...
entry.content:
To post goods receipts (PGR) against HU-based Inbound Deliveries (IBDs) and update the delivery/Goods Movement status via an incoming EDI 944, you should use one of the EWM-specific IDoc types rather than MBGMCR, DESADV or WMBBXY.

/SCWM/IDOC_GR or /SCWM/IDOC_GI are the two message types are delivered with EWM and are designed to handle HU-based IBDs. They carry full HU structure, update the IBD’s goods‐movement status, and set the HU statuses in one step.

Configuration steps would be in WE20, add your 3PL as partner, assign message type /SCWM/IDOC_GR (or /SCWM/IDOC_GI) and link to the appropriate basic type. In BD64, include the EWM logical system for inbound. Activate inbound processing for these IDocs under SPRO → Extended Warehouse Management → Interfaces → EDI → Inbound IDoc → Configure Message Types. Map the 944 fields (quantities, HU numbers, dates) to the IDoc segments in an ALE mapping project.

What happens is when SAP receives /SCWM/IDOC_GR, function modules like /SCWM/IDOC_PROCESS_GR process the IDoc, post the GR, and update the IBD lines and HU statuses. This approach is fully standard and has been adopted by other customers posting HU-based GRs via IDoc.

The next option is to go with SHPCON which is the Shipping Confirmation IDoc, originally intended for confirming PIC (packing) and PGI events. You can repurpose SHPCON to confirm a PGR by setting the qualifier fields for PGI (PMI) in segment E1EDT18.

Configuration steps would be in WE20, configure your 3PL partner with message type SHPCON and basic type DELVRY03. In BD64, add your EWM system. No further SPRO customizing is required—EWM’s inbound IDoc handler for SHPCON will update the IBD status. The key benefit is you leverage an already-released IDoc type to update both the HU‐ and delivery‐level GR status without custom coding. Several implementations use SHPCON for PGR—just map your EDI 944 to SHPCON segments (PIC vs. PGI indicators) and let EWM update the delivery

entry.title: Re: Need help with SP_TransactionNotification
entry.content: The new parameter User Id can be used in the TransactionNotification since SBO 10.0 FP 2108

entry.title: Re: Which is the bandwidth recommended between customer c...
entry.content:
Hi @AndersonCM 

According to the guidance on bandwidth requirements for connecting to RISE with SAP, there is no official SAP Note or document specifies an exact required bandwidth. However, SAP typically recommends 1 Mbps per user as a general guideline, depending on usage patterns. Note that, connectivity to RISE usually involves VPN, ExpressRoute, SD-WAN, or VNet peering, depending on the hyperscaler.

I suggest you raise a ticket to SAP directly during your onboarding to help you validate bandwidth needs for your specific use case.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP Cloud - Multiple Delivery addresses in Purchase Order
entry.content:
Dear community, 

our client is on SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public Edition.

We are facing the following challenge: We have 1 storage location but 6-8 different delivery points within the same storage location. We need the delivery address to be entered in the Purchase Order and print it on the PO form so that the supplier can send the goods to the right place.

As per standard, the delivery address in the PO is taken from the storage location (SLOC Configuration) - and we can maintain only one address for the SLOC in customizing. Of course, one possibility is to create an address table entry for each delivery point. The purchase could enter the address number during  PO creation. But that would mean that the PO creator has manual work: the right address needs to be entered n in each PO...

Does anyone have any idea to avoid or at least minimize the manual efforts?

Thanks and regards,

entry.title: Re: Local currency type not showing in finsc_ledger
entry.content:
When currency type 10 (“Company Code Currency”) isn’t selectable for a given company code in FINSC_LEDGER, it means it hasn’t been assigned in your ledger–company-code settings. You must explicitly map currency type 10 to your company code (PKCO) for the ledger in question. Follow these steps:

Execute transaction FINSC_LEDGER, select your Ledger (e.g. 0L for leading ledger) and click Details. From the menu, choose Company Code Settings for Ledger.In the pop-up, locate company code PKCO (add it if missing). In the “Currency Types” column, add 10 so it reads:

  • 00 (Document)
  • 10 (Company Code / Local)

Save your entries. After this, currency type 10 will be active (not greyed-out) for PKCO in FINSC_LEDGER.

Please note the Key consideration here is Currency type 10 and 00 are SAP-predefined; you cannot remove or rename them, only assign them at company-code level. If PKCO belongs to a controlling area with multiple company codes, ensure all share a consistent controlling-area currency in OKKP. Inconsistencies there can prevent assignment of type 10.

entry.title: Re: BUILD Work Zone - HTML5 Business Solutions vs HTML5 a...
entry.content:
Hello Fabio,

I will try to answer all your questions.

Please note that https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/simplifying-html5-content-consumption-across-subaccounts/ba-p/13758568?utm_source=chatgpt.com refers to a consumption of single tenant applications in Work Zone from across subaccounts.
I strongly recommend looking into this in-depth tutorial provided by the same author of the blog.
Link: https://www.youtube.com/live/rSw0BVHQzV0?si=vDxIJ-NIJYw6GcTZ&t=710

1) With single-tenant scenario you are not restricted to use a single BTP subaccount for development and deployment.
Similarly to the old "HTML5 Apps" content provider where your applications are deployed and consumed within the same subaccount, you still be able to deploy and consume the applications from the same subaccount, but additionally the cross-subaccount consumption were introduced.
With the cross-subaccount consumption you should be able to deploy your applications to subaccount A and consume the applications from subaccount B as long as the subaccounts share the same IAS tenant. e.g A subaccount is equivalent to a tenant.

2) The manifest.json of the application contain a sap.cloud.service property which is used to specify the business solution to which this html5 application belongs.
Business Solution can include a set of applications, not necessary a single application. there are some use-cases where different teams deploy single-tenant set of applications to multiple and then are consumed though a single Work Zone instance. The content providers still needs to be manually created at the moment, but we are currently exploring automatic discovery including creation of the content providers, especially in a cross-subaccount consumption where the only connection between the subaccounts is the IAS.

3) It is unfortunate to hear that you've experienced outages. The approach with new HTML5 Business Solutions is simpler, more resilient and robust.
You have full flexibility to distribute your front-end applications across multiple regions using separate BTP subaccounts. This is entirely your decision, based on your deployment and performance needs. As for the Managed Approuter no changes have been made to the SAP-managed AppRouter to support automatic traffic redirection.

4) The limitation in this context is that you won’t be able to use the same deployed front-end applications with both the “HTML5 Apps” content provider and the new CDM-based approach. The two approaches are not compatible and cannot be mixed. Specifically, you’ll need to deploy your UI5 applications to a new HTML5 Repository App Host instance aligned with the CDM model.

5) There are already vast adoption, I do not have the exact numbers unfortunately.

6) If by saas_approuter you are referring to the SAP-Managed approuter, there is currently no plans to deprecate this. in the future there will be an alternative which is based on Application Front End

  • https://help.sap.com/docs/application-frontend-service/application-frontend-service/what-is-application-frontend-service
  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/introducing-application-frontend-service/ba-p/14091408
  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/version-control-made-simple-with-application-frontend-service/ba-p/14152775
  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/exploring-application-frontend-service-deploying-the-ui-of-an-mta-app/ba-p/14149899

7) These limitations are still valid at the moment. The Work Zone team is working very hard on removing these limitations.

Thanks,
Jawad

entry.title: Re: How to calculate depreciation for multiple capitalizations across years in SAC?
entry.content:
Hi @MoonJun

1- Account Mapping

Account ID Description

CAPEX_001Annual Spending
CAPEX_002Capitalization
CAPEX_003Total Budget
CAPEX_004Depreciation
CAPEX_005Accumulated Depreciation
CAPEX_006Net Book Value
CAPEX_007Fixed Assets
CAPEX_011Actual Spending
CAPEX_012CWIP - Ideal
CAPEX_013CWIP - Final

2-The project dimension attribute for Energized year represent the year the project  should get capitalized. In my case its 2027

3- [d/DIM_BUDGETYEAR] is the column representing the budget year of the planning cycle.

4- @USEFULLIFE  value should be coming from project attribute and I am making it static for now as 30 years.

CC , Suptype 9, Bank ID 0, Bank ID-2 Block, Block days, Unblock, Ref. BuPa, CC Segment , Categ. , Src tax nbr. 

in the new version (we are in the phase to upgrade to S4 COREOP and S4DEPREC 108 the table  has a completely different name (now Synchronized HR data to supplier/customer and the settings are missing in 108.
Only the CC and Roles to synchronize  column's are available. 
e.g. Block days , unblock, ... as in 106 not available. 

Where are the remaining settings now maintained in 106, e.g., reference BuPa?
Where can I find more information about this?

many thanks

entry.title: Re: Batch Jobs for processing Billing document of Billing...
entry.content:
Hello  @Lily16 ,

thanks for raising your question in the community

For your scenario is see the challenge to pick only Billing Document Requests (BDR) only for Service Contracts. That means, you need to make sure that no BDR from Service Orders, Service Confirmations, or Professional Services.

I propose the following set-up of your job:

  • By filtering on Billing Type F2, BDRs from Professional Services are excluded as they use different Billing Types
  • By filtering on SD Document by the 10 digits number range, you can exclude BDRs from Service Orders and Confirmations because they use a 8 digits number rage

I hope this setup works for your scenarios as well.

Best regards,
Julius - SAP Cloud ERP Consulting

entry.title: Re: Import connection from FSM with SAC.
entry.content:
Hi @KUMARSURYASAI_KOTA42 

Thank you for your question.
Unfortunately, SAC’s OData query builder doesn’t currently support direct range filters. The User Interface only allows “Equal to” or “Except” options. As a workaround, we can either run multiple filtered imports using specific ID values or define filtered views on the FSM side if possible.

SAC has a soft cap of 100K records per import. To enable you handle larger datasets, I would suggest you split the load into smaller batches using the available filters, also ensure the FSM OData service supports pagination. If volumes grow significantly, you may consider a middleware e.g., CPI or SAP Data Intelligence to streamline your process.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Introducing SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC100) - our first classroom course now open for bookings
entry.content:
SAP Product and Solution Learning are pleased to announce our brand-new instructor-led course for SAP Business Data Cloud. This short, 4 hour course follows the same content as the free-of-charge, self-study course that is available on the SAP Learning Platform, but with the addition of an experienced instructor to guide you through the content, and to answer your questions. The course will help you quickly develop foundation skills in one of SAP's most important solutions. The course is run in a virtual classroom so you can attend this course wherever you happen to be. The course will include plenty of easy-to-follow content and will include demonstrations by the instructor using a SAP Business Data Cloud system.  You will receive a PDF handbook that includes all course content. The classes are run in English language. 

Click the link below to book your seat and we will see you in class.

Introducing SAP Business Data Cloud - BDC100 classroom course

entry.title: Re: SAP Cloud - Multiple Delivery addresses in Purchase O...
entry.content:
Yes you are right; by design a PO in Public Cloud only picks up a single address per storage location, so you must do extra work to support multiple “delivery points.” Below are the main approaches you can use to minimize manual entry:

Maintain each delivery point as an extra address on your vendor’s BP record. Use the Manage Business Partner Addresses Fiori app to add 6–8 addresses under your supplier.
In the PO’s Delivery Address tab, a field “Address Reference” lets you pick one of those BP addresses. Address numbers are generated when you enter a free-text address and save (or when you maintain them via the BP app). Once they exist, you can select the address number instead of typing the full street/block each time. But here, one drawback is, in the Create Purchase Order app, you cannot yet search or drop-down those address numbers. You can only key them in.

To avoid manual typing of the address number, you can use the Cloud’s Custom Logic (BAdI) framework:

In the Custom Business Objects (CBO) app, create a Custom Logic for the business object PurchaseOrder (BO Business Object: PurchaseOrder). Implement the “Before Save” hook to Read the PO’s Plant (or custom “Delivery Point” field you add), Look up your BP’s address table (via the standard CDS or API) to find the matching address number. Populate the PO item’s AddressReference property with that number. The end result would be when end users create or change a PO in the Create PO or Manage PO app, the system auto-fills the correct address number for them. They only override if absolutely necessary.

entry.title: Budget exceeds error through ko88 on some IO.
entry.content:
When I run the internal order settlement through ko88, it gives a budget exceed error on some internal orders, while when I run these internal order alone, it shows there is no line item found in SAP.

In actual there is no activity performed on these internal order then why the error occurs.

Please help me in resolving the issue. Thanks in advance.

entry.title: Re: SAP table PTRV_VENDOR_SYNC different S4Coreop 106 and...
entry.content:
In S/4HANA 106 and earlier, the table PTRV_VENDOR_SYNC (in component FI-TV) held all the Travel‐Management–driven settings for synchronizing HR infotype data into a vendor master, including block/unblock rules, reference vendor/Business Partner, bank‐ID overrides, tax-category sourcing, etc. In S/4HANA 108 these controls have been refactored into the Business Partner framework—and the old table is replaced by the generic Synchronized HR Data to Supplier/Customer customizing.

All the “missing” settings now live under the Business Partner SPRO node—instead of Travel Management. Open SPRO → Cross-Application Components → SAP Business Partner → Basic Settings → Synchronization of HR Data with Supplier/Customer. Within that activity, you’ll find sub‐nodes for

  • General Settings (defines CC, roles, BP grouping, reference BP)
  • Block/Unblock Rules (defines block indicator, block days and unblock logic)
  • Bank Determination (maps HR infotype-bank subtypes to BP bank-ID 1 & 2)
  • Tax Number Sourcing (maps infotype17 or other sources to BP tax category/number)

Whenever you transport these nodes, the system writes into the replaced table (now called something like /TM/VENDORSYNC in the background) and drives the new Business-Partner–based synchronization.

To see the underlying table, go to SE11, search for the DDIC structure TM_VENDORSYNC or TM_BP_SYNC. You’ll discover fields like BP_ROLE, BLOCK_IND, BLOCK_DAYS, REF_BUPA, BANK_TYPE1, BANK_TYPE2, TAXCAT, TAXSOURCE. This is the new “table behind the scenes” that replaces PTRV_VENDOR_SYNC.

You can read the Official Documentation by going to the S/4HANA 108 Help Library → “Business Partner” → “Basic Settings” → “Synchronization of HR Data.”

entry.title: Re: Budget exceeds error through ko88 on some IO.
entry.content: Hi @OmerFarooq  - you might wanted to check all the open transactions against these IO, example - there might be Purchase Requisition or Purchase orders created but no receipts, hence budget is showing consumed.

entry.title: Re: Budget exceeds error through ko88 on some IO.
entry.content:
Before any settlement posting is created, the system runs a budget check (availability control). By default, it sums:

  • Actuals (CO postings)
  • Commitments (purchase orders, requisitions,schedules)
  • Planned settlements (costs that will be settled in this KO88 run)

Even if your order has zero actuals, it might still have commitments or be slated to receive costs via settlement from other orders. That “would-be” settled value is pulled into the check—and can tip you over the budget limit.

Some common reasons why you get Budget errors on "Empty" orders are

Order is a Settlement Receiver If other orders use your order as a receiver in their settlement rules (check in KO04 for “Receiver = Internal Order”), KO88 in collective run mode will plan to settle their costs to yours—and include that planned amount in the availability check.

Open Commitments Purchase orders or requisitions account-assigned to the order consume budget under the “commitment” ledger. Use the Fiori app “Manage Internal Order Budgets” or report S_ALR_87013019 (Budget/Actual/Commitments) to see these.

Statistical Re-postings (Asset Settlements) If your order is used in Asset Accounting (AuC), the settlement to AuC and the subsequent statistical repost back to the order (via ACSET customizing) can re-debit the order—without leaving a visible CO document line in KOB1—and drive you into an overrun.


To diagnose this,
Check Settlement Rules – Transaction KO04 → Enter your order → Display → Settlement rule “Receiver” tab. – Is the order listed as a receiver for other orders?

Check Commitments – Run S_ALR_87013019 or use KOB2 for plan line items. – Look for commitments > 0 against that order.

Simulate Availability Check – Go to SPRO → Controlling → Internal Orders → Budgeting & Avail. Control → Availability Control in Settlement → Choose “Test Availability Control” for your order and date. – You’ll see exactly which components (actual, planned, commit­ments) are triggering the block.


To fix this

Exclude Receiver Orders from Collective Run On the KO88 selection screen, uncheck “Collective Run” or use variant settings so only orders with actual postings get picked up.

Adjust Tolerance Limits SPRO → Controlling → Internal Orders → Budgeting & Avail. Control → Define Tolerance Limits for Availability Control. Increase tolerance or turn the error into a warning.

Remove Statistical Re-debits In ACSET, deselect the “AccntAssgnmt” flag for the relevant movement types so assets don’t re-debit the order after settlement.

Clear Up Commitments Release or close purchase requisitions/POs tied to the order, or shift their account assignment away, so they no longer consume budget.

entry.title: How to set Application Version for MDK Client?
entry.content:
How can I set  or find the Application Version of an MDK Client?

I am trying to restrict access to only certain compatible MDK Clients compatible with the metadata data deployed. There is a setting in Security to restrict client by Application Version. But I could not find how this can be set for an MDK Client.

Security / Application Version

 For an Android Build of MDK Client, I tried to set this in app.gradle as suggested in Application Versioning documentation for Android. This succeeded in onboarding the client, but failed later when synching with an error from Mobilink. So that is not the correct approach. 

I suppose there is a correct way to do this with MDK.

entry.title: Error al cancelar asiento
entry.content:

Tengo un cliente que está trabajando con la versión 10.00.280. nos hemos encontrado el problema que cuando vamos a cancelar un asiento nos borra el importe de la primera linea y como nos deja editarlo nos indica el erro de que el asiento no esta compensado.

Ejemplo:

Tengo un asiento:

hacemos click derecho en cancelar

Como veis me elimina el saldo de la primera linea, sin posibilidad de ser editado y por correspondiente cancelado, ya que el asiento no está compensado.

Al intentar tres o cuatro veces el intento de cancelar acaba haciendo bien el asiento y permite cancelarlo.

 

¿alguna idea de porque no arrastra bien los saldos al cancelar?

 

un saludo

entry.title: How to delete Assignment in Public cloud SCCUI 104795 (Define Splitting Structure)？
entry.content:
Dear all：

I added a new Assignment in Public cloud SCCUI 104795 (Define Splitting Structure), and I want to delete it, but I found that deleting it is grayed out and impossible. How can I delete it?

Thank you &Best Regards.

Wang

entry.title: Re: Groovy scrit error when canonicalize XML subtree
entry.content:
Hi @Chris1973 

Thanks for this suggestion, Actually I had used the cannicalize() too replace the canonicalizeSubtree().

After that it will fix the type mismatch error, but it will brings a new problem:

In the original xml document before canonicalize, the namespace declaration are centrally put in the root </invoice> element just as below:

<Invoice xmlns="urn:oasis:names:specification:ubl:schema:xsd:Invoice-2" xmlns:cac="urn:oasis:names:specification:ubl:schema:xsd:CommonAggregateComponents-2" xmlns:cbc="urn:oasis:names:specification:ubl:schema:xsd:CommonBasicComponents-2">
<cbc:ID>Test</cbc:ID>
<cbc:IssueDate>2025-07-31</cbc:IssueDate>
<cbc:IssueTime>13:00:19Z</cbc:IssueTime>
<cbc:InvoiceTypeCode listVersionID="1.1">01</cbc:InvoiceTypeCode>
<cbc:DocumentCurrencyCode>EUR</cbc:DocumentCurrencyCode>
<cbc:TaxCurrencyCode>EUR</cbc:TaxCurrencyCode>

However after canonicalize() run, the namespace declaration will be separated into each child element just as below sample:

<Invoice xmlns="urn:oasis:names:specification:ubl:schema:xsd:Invoice-2">
  <cbc:ID xmlns:cbc="urn:oasis:names:specification:ubl:schema:xsd:CommonBasicComponents-2">Test</cbc:ID>
  <cbc:IssueDate xmlns:cbc="urn:oasis:names:specification:ubl:schema:xsd:CommonBasicComponents-2">2025-07-31</cbc:IssueDate>
  <cbc:IssueTime xmlns:cbc="urn:oasis:names:specification:ubl:schema:xsd:CommonBasicComponents-2">13:00:19Z</cbc:IssueTime>
  <cbc:InvoiceTypeCode xmlns:cbc="urn:oasis:names:specification:ubl:schema:xsd:CommonBasicComponents-2" listVersionID="1.1">01</cbc:InvoiceTypeCode>
  <cbc:DocumentCurrencyCode xmlns:cbc="urn:oasis:names:specification:ubl:schema:xsd:CommonBasicComponents-2">EUR</cbc:DocumentCurrencyCode>
  <cbc:TaxCurrencyCode xmlns:cbc="urn:oasis:names:specification:ubl:schema:xsd:CommonBasicComponents-2">EUR</cbc:TaxCurrencyCode>

The program will next steps use the canonicalized XMl to do the SHA-256 hash and Base 64 encode, then signing based on that digest .As a result the information in invoice  cannot match with the original invoice before canonicalize.

The basic logic is that the invoice verification system will also digest the original invoice, and compare the digest value with the result in signature. In this case the digest value will be different, because the invoice payload was changed after canonicalize.

Sincerely grateful for any suggestion which can avoid the namespace and format changed during the canonicalize() method run.

Thanks again!!

BR,

Ivan

entry.title: Re: Unable to see list data when I run the app
entry.content:
Hello @Ankita_Mundhra 

If you're using SAP Build Apps (or AppGyver):

Your integration query already fetches data successfully.

The issue lies in how that data is being linked to your UI, not the query itself.

As long as your data variable is correctly set to autoload and the UI is properly bound to that variable, the data should display.

Please double-check below

Is the data variable set to autoload?
If not, set it to autoload or use page logic to trigger it.

Is the UI element (e.g., table or list) bound to the data variable — not the query?
Must be bound to the data variable, not the integration directly.

Is the data structure correct and accessible?
Use a temporary text element:{{ JSON.stringify(yourDataVariable) }}

This shows what’s actually in the variable during runtime.

Let me know if it works

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: freight-cost-condition divided per position in outbound delivery the same as at sales documents.
entry.content:
For example situation now : 

ZFRE= our freight-condition. | ZFRE= 10 euro. 

So order situation:

Product X | 2 pieces | 10 euro p/piece | therefore : ZFRE = 10/25*20 = 8 euro. 

  • 10 = ZFRE-freight. 
  • 25 comes from 10+10+5 total document costs.
  • 20=10+10 this position.

Product Y | 1 piece | 5 euro p/piece | therefore : ZFRE = 10/25*5 = 2 euro. 

  • 10 = ZFRE-freight. 
  • 25 comes from 10+10+5 total document costs.
  • 5= this position.

first outbound delivery / billing document:

Product X with 1 less piece:

Product X | 1 pieces | 10 euro | therefore : ZFRE = 10/25*10 = 4 euro. 

Product Y | 1 piece | 5 euro | therefore : ZFRE = 10/25*5 = 2 euro. 

SAP waits for next outbound deliveries for further ZFRE of 10-4-2=4 euro on position 1. 

--------------------------------------------------

Question: how to:

order situation same:

Product X | 2 pieces | 10 euro p/piece | therefore : ZFRE = 10/25*20 = 8 euro. 

Product Y | 1 piece | 5 euro p/piece | therefore : ZFRE = 10/25*5 = 2 euro. 

first delivery/billing document:

Product X with 1 piece on position 1 : 

Product X | 1 pieces |10 euro | ZFRE = 10/15*10 = 6.67 euro. 

Product Y | 1 piece |5 euro | ZFRE=10/15*5 = 3.33 euro. 

 

So we want:

At first delivery we want the 10 euro freight divided but calculated based on positions at outbound delivery. Next upcoming deliveries are then without freight costs because it is already payed. How could we do this ?

entry.title: How to Count Table Entries with a Custom KPI
entry.content:
With custom KPIs in Business Process Monitoring, you can enrich the application with further KPIs tailored to your needs. 

SAP Cloud ALM: Business Process Monitoring

This blog will explain how custom KPIs in Business Process Monitoring in SAP Cloud ALM can be used to count entries in a table.
It is a simple example, aiming to inspire what's in and what you could do.

 

General Information

The general process for a custom KPI is as follows:

Process Flow: Custom KPIs

The process for custom KPIs starts with their definition, followed by general and KPI-specific steps, and ends with using custom KPIs.

And in addition, the detailed flow for custom KPI for an ABAP-based component, which we will now follow:

Process Flow: Custom KPI for ABAP-based components

If you would like to learn more about custom KPIs, our Expert Portal (Custom KPIs) and the SAP Help Portal (Custom KPIs) are amazing places to go to. 

 

Before you Begin

Here are three things that are relevant before you can start:

  • In order to use a custom KPI for an ABAP-based component, the respective setup for Business Process Monitoring needs to be completed, and active, successful data collection is needed. You can find all relevant details on the Expert Portal: Custom KPIs - Prerequisites and Setup 
  • To define a custom KPI, you need to have the role of Process Monitoring Administrator
  • For the instrumentation of the KPI, bring some ABAP development knowledge

Let's get started with some context.

 

Context

We will create a custom KPI for ABAP-based components. As data model - tables for which we will count entries the famous sflight model.

As a result, the following queries shall be covered by the KPI:

  1. Total number of flights
  2. Number of flights operated with a 737-800
  3. Number of single flight bookings
  4. Number of flights that are scheduled
  5. Number of flights operated with a 777-300

Let's follow the steps mentioned above.

 

Steps for a Custom KPI

The following section will guide you through the process that results in a custom KPI. In the section "Use Custom KPI", you can also find examples of events based on the counters above. 

 

A) General Business Process Monitoring Steps

In order to use a custom KPI for an ABAP-based component, the respective setup for Business Process Monitoring needs to be completed, and active, successful data collection is needed.

You can find all relevant details on the Expert Portal: Custom KPIs - Prerequisites and Setup 

 

B) Custom KPI Definition

As this example will offer all checks collectively in a single KPI, this is how the KPI is defined:

Technical IDLabel
IDID
Field1Check No
Field2Table
Field3Number of Entries
Field4 Additional Criteria 1
Field5  Additional Criteria 2
Field6Label
TIMESTAMP_UTCTimestamp

In the Business Process Monitoring application

  • Open the configuration panel
  • Expand the sections Managed Components > KPI Management
  • Choose Configure KPIs
  • In the KPI Management, choose + to Create a Custom KPI

For information and characteristics, specify the relevant details – in our example

InformationCharacteristics
Name: Flight Counters
Description: Flight Counters
KPI ID: ZKPITA0999
Category: Backlog
Data Collection Frequency: 15 Minutes		FIELD_1 Check No
FIELD_2 Table
FIELD_3 Number of Entries
FIELD_4 Additional Criteria 1
FIELD_5 Additional Criteria 2
FIELD_6 Label 

Result:

Business Process Monitoring: KPI Definition

 

C) Instrument KPI

The following steps show the instrumentation in the managed component and require ABAP development knowledge:

  • Create a subclass of /SDF/CL_CRBPA_CKPI:
    Instrumentation: Class Properties
  • Redefine method GET_KPI_ID and GET_DATA:
    Instrumentation: Redefined Methods
    Instrumentation: Method GET_KPI_IDInstrumentation: Method GET_DATA

 

D) Auto-Discovery and Data Collection

These steps are taken care of automatically for you based on our framework.

No manual activities required - only giving it some time 😉

 

E) Use Custom KPI

The result in the application looks as follows:

Business Process Monitoring: KPI Details

Let's proceed with the definition of an Event: to receive an email notification.

 

Define Event

What would be a KPI without an event or being alerted? Let's have a look at two examples, one for counter 2 and the second for counter 5.

Here is the definition for getting an alert if there are results for counter 2:
Business Process Monitoring: Event Definition Counter 2

And as you can see in the KPI details above, relevant entries are found - the resulting notification: 

Event: Notification

Similarly, you can also define an event for counter 5 - this looks as follows
Business Process Monitoring: Event Definition Counter 5

In this case, the expected result is no email. Currently, there is no flight in the data that is operated with 777-300. Once there is a respective data set, it will be identified as part of the next data collection, with this visible in the KPI details. Based on the event definition, an alert and email notification will be triggered. 

 

Summarizing

So let's summarize: this blog explains, based on an example, how to use a custom KPI to count table entries.

We chose the way, one single KPI that covers all counters. Many other options are possible. So it is now your turn to get started!

Happy to hear from you how you used it, so feel free to leave a comment below.

entry.title: Where can I start learning how to manage SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition implementations?
entry.content:
I recommend to access our Managing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition Projects   learning journey.

Overview
This Learning Journey is designed for experienced SAP professionals, including project managers, consultants, and technical leads, who seek to enhance their skills in managing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition implementations. It is particularly suited for individuals aspiring to advance their careers by taking on strategic, high-level roles in cloud-based project delivery and enterprise integration.

Learning objectives
Within this Learning Journey, SAP project managers can deepen their expertise of managing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition implementations, specifically focusing on SAP tools, methodologies, and SAP Business Suite portfolio.

This Learning Journey will lead to the certification "Managing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition Projects", which includes courses on the following subjects:

  1. Exploring SAP Activate - Implementation Tools and Methodology
  2. Implementing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  3. Discovering Organizational Change Management for SAP Cloud Projects
  4. Introducing the RISE with SAP Methodology for SAP Partners and Customers

Prerequisites

  • Project Management Experience: Minimum of 5–7 years managing ERP implementation projects, preferably SAP Cloud-related
  • SAP Expertise: Hands-on experience with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, including system deployment, configuration, and lifecycle management
  • Cloud Implementation Experience: Proven track record in managing cloud-based SAP projects, including understanding of SaaS models

Please post you question related to the digital learning Journey in the Q&A area. 
Our SAP Learning Experts will get back to you as soon as possible! 
We are here to support you.


I appreciate your feedback and we will make sure to continue sharing interesting topics.

entry.title: Have You Heard About Service Management Solutions from SAP?
entry.content:
How One Service Call Turned Into a Business Breakthrough

It started with a broken compressor on a hot summer day.

Anna, a service manager at an industrial equipment company, got the call: a key customer’s machine had failed—and production was at risk. The clock was ticking, and the pressure was on. In the past, resolving a case like this would have meant a flurry of phone calls, digging through disconnected systems for warranty info, manually checking technician availability, and hoping the right spare part was in stock.

But not this time.

Thanks to SAP’s end-to-end Service Management solution, Anna’s team had everything they needed in one place—from customer contract details and installed base info to intelligent technician scheduling, mobile field execution, and real-time updates. Within hours, the right technician was on-site with the correct spare part. The issue was fixed before it became a crisis.

And the customer? Still a customer. More loyal than ever.

Service: The New Competitive Edge

In today’s service economy, it’s no longer enough to sell great products. Customers expect fast, reliable, and proactive service. That’s where Service Management solutions from SAP come in—helping companies like Anna’s turn every service interaction into a competitive advantage.

SAP connects the dots across your entire service lifecycle, from the initial request to billing and performance analysis. It’s not just about solving issues—it’s about transforming service into a strategic driver of growth, loyalty, and efficiency.

What’s Included in SAP’s Service Management Offering?

 

🛒Sell, Contract, and Engage

  • Manage subscriptions and complex service contracts with Services in SAP Cloud ERP.

  • Provide fast, omnichannel support via SAP Service Cloud.

📦Plan, Optimize, and Orchestrate

  • Predict equipment failures with SAP Asset Performance Management.

  • Ensure parts and labor are ready when needed with integrated planning tools.

🧭 Schedule and Execute

  • Use AI-powered scheduling in SAP Field Service Management to dispatch the right technician at the right time.

  • Empower your field force with intuitive mobile apps—even when offline.

💰Invoice and Close

  • Automate warranty handling, returns, and billing with Finance in SAP Cloud ERP.

  • Gain full visibility into service profitability and cost-to-serve.

Why Do Customers Choose SAP?

Because SAP doesn’t just offer tools—it offers transformation.

 

✅Integrated by Design

Service Management solutions from SAP are part of the broader SAP Business Suite. That means seamless handovers, no duplicate data entry, and no fragile third-party integrations.

✅Built for Intelligence

With SAP Business AI and automation embedded, SAP helps your team make smarter decisions—faster.

✅Flexible and Future-Proof

Whether you’re scaling field operations, managing complex SLAs, or building a partner network, SAP adapts to your service strategy.

From One Service Call to a Strategic Shift

Back to Anna: what started as one resolved breakdown evolved into a deeper realization. With SAP, her company didn’t just fix machines faster—they started rethinking service delivery entirely. Today, they offer predictive maintenance packages, use data to improve uptime, and collaborate more closely with partners.

Service became more than a cost center. It became a value engine.

Curious How It Could Work for You?

Let’s talk. We’ll show you how SAP Service Management can help you:

  • Streamline your service processes

  • Improve customer satisfaction

  • Boost service revenue

  • Make sustainability a differentiator

👉Contact us to schedule a demo or learn more.

entry.title: Re: validity update in mass changes to purchasing info re...
entry.content:
You need to:

  • Maintain 'X' in column Is New so a new record is created
  • In the condition group ID field, maintain new dummy nrs (just 1,2,3,4,5 etc) and update the validaty period from date with the new period for the new condition, a new condition record will be created
  • No need to put end date in the existing condition item line like the other commenter has said. you can just overwrite that data with new data and it will delimit that condition record automatically when you create the new one.

entry.title: Re: BAS Connection to On-Premises System Failing with 'Re...
entry.content:
Hi @s_sudhirkumar 

Based on the behaviour you mentioned, the problem is likely tied to certain configuration mismatches between BAS and the backend system despite the destination working in Build Apps and BTP cockpit.

To evaluate the source, I suggest you do the following:

  • Ensure your Cloud Connector mappings are correctly set up and the system is marked as “Available”.
  • Make sure to confirm that the OData service is active in SICF and properly whitelisted.
  • Double-check that your destination settings in BTP match what is expected by BAS
  • If needed, you can enable backend trace like ST01 or SMICM to catch dropped connections or blocked services.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SD: Rundungsdifferenzen bei der Fakturierung
entry.content:
Bei der Fakturierung eines SD-Auftrages mit folgenden Konditionen:

6 Stück zu 35.000,00 Euro wird ein prozentualer Zuschlag von 9% hinterlegt und SAP ermittelt korrekt einen Zuschlag von 3.150,00 Euro pro Stück.
Bei der Fakturierung wird dann allerdings ein Zuschlag von3.149,98 ermittelt und 2 Cent werden als Rundungsdifferenz ausgewiesen.

entry.title: Re: BW: True impact of build statistics in cubes.
entry.content:
Hi @luisaguilar 

Thanks for your question.

SAP generally recommends that you update statistics as follows:

  • After each full load or major delta load to the InfoCube, especially if data volume has changed significantly.
  • Not necessarily after every delta, unless the volume or pattern significantly impacts data distribution.

Regarding the data requirement:

  • For Oracle, SAP suggests you build statistics on a representative sample, though this can be tuned based on data skew.
  • For HANA, it's less critical because HANA auto-manages statistics, but for classic BW on non-HANA DBs scheduling statistics explicitly is beneficial.

Here is what I recommend:

Include "Build Statistics" in process chains after heavy loads but avoid overuse for minor delta updates.

Optionally, you can set thresholds or conditional branches to execute statistics only if the load exceeds a certain volume.

To summarize, updating statistics after large or full loads helps significantly improve query performance by enabling better data access planning. For smaller delta loads, it's not always necessary unless there's a major shift in data volume or distribution.

For non-HANA databases, including the "Build Statistics" step in process chains post-load is recommended. Ideally use a sample percentage of approximately 10% to balance performance and accuracy. HANA manages this more automatically, so the need is less critical there.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

- It becomes harder because of 2 different approaches & visualization styles in tables & charts variances.

There have been quite some influence requests related to these topics with a LOT of votes, so I would suggest you vote for at least these 2 requests:
https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/275936 
https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/308765

entry.title: Re: Unable to completely terminate a TRM Transaction
entry.content:
When you “Give Notice/Terminate” an FTR deal in FTR_EDIT and settle all cash-flows, you still need to trigger its final business event so that the activity status flips to “Completed/Contract Settled.” If you skip that, the system sees the deal as still active—and reprotects it against further termination attempts, leading to BS013.

Here’s how to close the loop:

In FTR_EDIT, open your deal and choose Goto → Cash Flows. Confirm no lines are left “Flagged for Fixing” or “To Be Processed.” If any remain: Select them → “Fix Pay & Post.” Save and refresh until the list is empty. When zero flows remain, you’re ready for the final event.

In FTR_EDIT, open the same deal. Click Additional Functions → Post Business Events. In the popup, select the termination event (usually event type “900 – Contract Termination” or your custom variant). Execute. This step writes the termination into the deal’s event log and officially closes the contract in SAP’s event processor.

Once the termination event is posted, go back in FTR_EDIT, refresh the header. The Activity Status should now read “Completed” or “Contract Settled.” Save your deal again. If status doesn’t update, it often means the event wasn’t processed or there’s a custom event determination gap.

entry.title: Re: SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model: Modeling Update (Join)
entry.content:
@Paulo_Moncada

We would like to express our concern regarding the recent changes to the join function, specifically the inability to select fields from individual join rules in the final join configuration. This functionality was previously available and played a crucial role in streamlining our solutions.

Unfortunately, the current limitation has significantly increased our effort and complexity, making the process more cumbersome. It has now been over three months without a resolution, and we are increasingly dissatisfied with the way recent releases have been rolled out—often without sufficient support or consideration for customer impact.

We strongly believe that the ability to copy fields from each individual join rule, rather than solely from the function signature, is a more flexible and user-friendly approach. This was a key feature in the previous version and should be considered essential moving forward.

We kindly request that this issue be prioritized and addressed at the earliest possible opportunity. If a fix is already planned or in progress, we would appreciate insights into the expected timeline for delivery.

Thank you for your attention to this matter. We look forward to your response and a resolution that restores the usability we previously relied on.

Best regards,

Gopi Akkapeddi

entry.title: Setting Up Individual Goals in PMGM with Varying Targets | Metric-LookUp Table
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

At our company, we use individual goals in the Performance and Goal Management module, each with different target levels (=Targets).

Since the SAP release H01/2025, we’ve encountered an issue in the Performance & Goals module: we can no longer set individual target levels for our goals. Instead, the same target levels are shown for all individual goals. Even when we adjust and save the target levels for a specific individual goal in SuccessFactors, the changes are not applied. SuccessFactors continues to display the default target levels used for all individual goals (please see the screenshots below).

For example, when we try to adjust the target levels for the individual goal "EBIT Asia" (Screenshot 1) and then click save, the system still shows the targets 0, 100, and 200 (Screenshot 2).

Screenshot 1: Trying to change the target levels of the individual goal "EBIT ASIA" by clicking "save"

Screenshot 2: SAP SuccessFactors does not consider the saved changes and continues to show the target levels 0, 100, 200

 

 

We assume that the values 0, 100, and 200 are defined in the Metric Lookup Table in the XML file, which is why they are always shown as default for individual goals.

Now that we have the issue of needing different targets for different individual goals, but the system only displays the same targets for all, my question is:
Is there a way to configure the system so that each individual goal can have its own target level again?
Or has anyone else experienced this issue and found a solution?

Many thanks in advance for your help.

entry.title: Re: Error in calling Outbound Delivery public API in iflo...
entry.content:
Hi @Priyanka488 

Thank you for your question.

Based on the details you provided, the error you're facing in your iFlow when calling the API_OUTBOUND_DELIVERY_SRV via the OData V2 Receiver Adapter stems from an improperly formatted query string specifically. It refers to how the “&” characters are used in the select, expand, and filter parts of the URL.

SAP confirms this as a known issue (see SAP Note 2510796), where the adapter throws an internal parsing error if & characters are misplaced.

To fix it, make sure your query string is well-structured.

Once the URL syntax is corrected, your GET request should work as expected.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: HI guys

entry.title: Re: Issue with Translating Simulation into English
entry.content:
Hello @Helenka ,

Yes, you can use the "Export Translation File" functionality for simulations, including Demo, Practice, and Test modes in SAP Enable Now (cloud or on-premise). However, there are a few important things to note:

  1. All Modes Must Be Generated
    Ensure that Demo, Practice, and Test modes are already generated for each simulation. Otherwise, they won’t be included in the export file.
  2. Structure Consistency
    If some simulations are not exporting correctly, check:
  • If their structure deviates from standard templates
  • If any screens or steps are incomplete or corrupted
  • If language placeholders are missing

3.Use Translation Hub or External Tools
Once you export the XLIFF translation file, you can use tools like:

  • SAP Translation Hub
  • Third-party CAT tools (e.g., SDL Trados, MemoQ)

After translating, you can re-import the file to update the original simulation content in bulk.

4. Check Project Type
Only multilingual projects allow full translation export. Confirm your project settings are set to support multiple languages.

Troubleshooting Tip

  • If some simulations are still excluded:
  • Open one of the problematic simulations
  • Regenerate all three modes (Demo, Practice, Test)
  • Save and try exporting again

SAP Help Confirmation: SAP Enable Now Help Portal – Translations

Let me know if it works

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Need Help Converting Functional Specification to CDS...
entry.content:
Hi,

Here are the steps on how to build CDS views in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. The Functional Specification Document from you needs deeper review from a dedicated consultant, though. 

Prerequisites

  • Ensure you have the "Extensibility" business catalog assigned to your business role [1]
  • Access to the Custom CDS Views application through the Fiori Launchpad

Step-by-Step Process

1. Access the Custom CDS Views Application

  • Navigate to the "Custom CDS Views" tile in your Fiori Launchpad [2]
  • Click "Create" to start building a new custom CDS view [3]

2. Define Basic Properties

  • Label: Provide a descriptive name for your CDS view
  • Name: Enter a technical name following SAP naming conventions
  • Scenario: Select the appropriate scenario:
    • Analytical: For reporting and analytics use cases
    • Transactional: For operational scenarios
    • Value Help: For dropdown lists and search helps [4]

3. Configure Data Sources

  • Primary Data Source: Select your main CDS view from the available released views [1]
  • Associated Data Sources: Add related views as needed
  • Define join conditions between data sources with appropriate cardinality settings [3]

4. Select Elements and Fields

  • Navigate to the "Elements" tab
  • Choose fields from your primary and associated data sources
  • Configure field properties such as:
    • Labels and descriptions
    • Data types
    • Aggregation behaviors for analytical scenarios [3]

5. Add Calculations and Logic

  • Implement calculations directly within the custom CDS view
  • Use built-in functions and expressions for data transformation
  • For analytical scenarios, add restricted measures and calculated measures [5]

6. Define Parameters and Filters

  • Set up input parameters for dynamic filtering
  • Configure default values and validation rules
  • Add selection criteria to optimize data retrieval [1]

7. Testing and Validation

  • Use the "Data Preview" function to verify your CDS view structure
  • Check for any errors or warnings in the system logs
  • Validate that all joins and calculations work correctly [3]

8. Publish and Activate

  • Click "Check" to validate the CDS view definition
  • Resolve any issues identified during the check
  • Click "Publish" to activate your custom CDS view [3]

Best Practices

  • Follow SAP's content guidelines as outlined in SAP Note 2540696 [6]
  • Implement proper authorization checks for data security
  • Use meaningful names and descriptions for better maintainability
  • Test thoroughly with representative data volumes
  • Consider performance implications when joining multiple data sources

Integration Options

  • Analytics: Use with Custom Analytical Queries for reporting [5]
  • External APIs: Expose as OData services for external consumption [2]
  • Custom Fields: Extend with custom fields created through Key User Extensibility [7]

[1]: How to Create Custom CDS Views for SAP Marketing Cloud

[2]: Custom CDS Views – Frequently Asked Questions

[3]: How to create CDS View Report In RISE With SAP Public Cloud 2208

[4]: Overview of S/4HANA Cloud reporting capabilities utilizing custom CDS views and eSAC - Part 1

[5]: Custom Logic for the fields in Custom CDS (S4 Public Cloud)
[6]: Custom CDS Views
[7]: How to Extend Custom Fields for a Custom CDS View in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
 
Best regards, Dequan Xu

entry.title: Introducing the Get Certified Series for SAP Customer Data Cloud
entry.content:
We are thrilled to announce the launch of our new live session series: Get Certified for SAP Customer Data Cloud. This series is designed to help you prepare for and succeed in the C_C4H62 certification: SAP Certified Associate - Implementation Consultant - SAP Customer Data Cloud. Our certified expert trainers will guide you through all the relevant topic areas, ensuring you have the best chance of passing the certification exam.

Series Overview

The Get Certified live session series aims to provide you with expert-guided support to complement your self-study activities. By participating in these sessions, you will gain a deeper understanding of the exam format, scope, and key topics, enhancing your readiness to attempt the certification.

Prerequisites

To make the most of this series, we recommend that you:

  • Attend our Instructional-Led-Training.
  • Work through the learning journeys linked to this blog post.
  • Perform the hands-on practice exercises.
  • Join all the live sessions to benefit from the trainer's expertise and insights.

Session Breakdown

Each session will focus on specific topics relevant to the C_C4H62 certification exam. Here’s a breakdown of the content covered in each session:

Session 1: Kick Off (1 hour)

  • Outlining the live session series
  • Introducing the certification
  • Explaining the types of questions
  • Providing tips for preparation
  • Working through sample questions in the exam interface

Session 2: SAP Customer Identity and Access (2 hours)

  • Deep dive into SAP Customer Identity and Access
  • Key concepts and practical applications
  • Exam-focused insights and tips

Session 3: SAP Customer Data Cloud Authentication Methods (1 hour)

  • Understanding various authentication methods
  • Best practices and implementation strategies
  • Exam preparation for authentication topics

Session 4: SAP Enterprise Consent and Preference Management (1 hour)

  • Exploring consent and preference management in SAP Customer Data Cloud
  • How to configure and manage consent
  • Practical tips for the exam

Session 5: Developing and Integration with SAP Customer Data Cloud (2 hours)

  • Development and integration techniques
  • Hands-on exercises and best practices
  • Exam-specific guidance

Learning Objectives

By the end of this Get Certified live session series, you will be well-prepared to:

  • Understand the format and scope of the C_C4H62 certification exam.
  • Master key topics related to SAP Customer Data Cloud, including identity and access, authentication methods, consent and preference management, and integration techniques.
  • Feel confident in attempting the C_C4H62 certification exam.

Relevant Learning Journeys

To maximize your preparation(best before attending the get certified series), review the following Trainings and Learning Journeys:

  • Managing Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • SAP Customer Data Cloud Implementation Training  
  • Exploring SAP Customer Data Cloud Essentials
  • From Onboarding to Governance: Mastering SAP Customer Data Cloud for B2B

How to Participate

 

For registration, simply log in with your valid Learning Hub subscription (for SAP internal teams, it’s FREE) and register to reserve your spot.

Get ready to enhance your SAP skills and take your career to the next level with the Get Certified Series for SAP Customer Data Cloud!

Don’t miss this opportunity to become a certified SAP Customer Data Cloud Implementation Consultant. See you in the sessions!

entry.title: Re: How do I export the results for Import Performance Go...
entry.content:
Hi ea22,

I'm afraid currently the goal import result is only available through the email.

If you want to have this functionality changed, you can submit an enhancement request through our Continuous Influence page, 2090228 - How to Submit Ideas for SAP SuccessFactors Products is attached to guide you.

Continuous Influence is a great program for customers and partners to share feedback / ideas that help enhance SAP solutions in production. It enables customers to submit ideas and to vote on them.

BR,
Yilin
